text: PUSH across a leaf-strewn lawn to find a GIRL, eight, wit long braids, staring at an abandoned Victorian house that fallen into grave disrepair. Shutters missing, paint peeling...an ingenue turned dowager by the march of time. Suddenly, a rock whizzes by the girl’s head and SHATTERS upper story window. She turns and we finally SEE her face This is ADELAIDE, and she has Down Syndrome. TWO BOYS, TEN, bash a gate open with a baseball bat and s into the yard. This is Troy and Bryan...the Rutger twins.
Hey, retard. They head into the empty derelict house, on a mission. Adelaide suddenly speaks.
Excuse me. They stop, turn.
You’re going to die in there. They stare at her a beat, the moment is shocking. Then Tr runs to her, viciously pushes her to the ground. He regar her, spits on her, then heads back into the house.

CLASSICAL music plays. FLASHLIGHT BEAMS illuminate stunni Victorian fixtures as they are shattered by the bat. Lead stained glass, intricate moldings...the destruction is horrifying and complete, punctuated by the loud gunshot firecracker sound of SNAP and POPS the boys throw everywh
Troy bashes stunningly beautiful leaded cabinets, shatter the glass. Suddenly, with alarm from another room --
Troy!

We are on Troy’s face as he slowly makes his way across t empty room. All we HEAR is the sound of flies...a faint buzzing, then a cacophony. He finally stops near where hi brother is standing and kneels down.

Awesome. He is looking at a dead gutted POSSUM...someone, somethin has feasted here. The possum’s face is frozen and twisted fear. ANGLE: the boys crouching reflection in the gray fl dead eye of the animal. Just then, a NOISE. Faint childis LAUGHTER. Adelaide? The boys investigate. They walk down the hall, when suddenly a BASEMENT DOOR at other end slowly creaks opens. The boys freeze, then --
(afraid) Go.
You go, shithead. A dare. Troy moves forward. His brother follows.
A murky soup, the flashlights cut a swath. The beams illuminate the odd stray cobweb, nothing much d here. The boys split up to investigate, Troy throwing the snap and pop. Until --

Check it out. Bryan approaches and stares with wonder. The flashlights illuminate a wall of dusty SPECIMEN JARS filled with yell viscous fluid. Within the fluid: monstrosities. Severed deformed hands, feet, a twisted jaw...a horrifying tablea the style of Joel Peter Witkin. Next to the jars: a neat line of surgical equipment. Clam disembowelers, spreaders...all caked in rusty blood. A moment of awe from the boys. WE SEE (but they don’t) something move behind them. A flash of white. Troy picks up one of the jars, studies, it.
Don’t. But Troy smashes it against a wall, it shatters.
It stinks down here. It stinks like shit. (beat) Last summer, when we had a raccoon stuck in the chimney? That’s what it smells like. Let’s go find it.

No, it smells bad. I’m going. Bryan starts off. Troy starts investigating, throwing the snap and pops. Bryan is half way up the stairs, when the and pops ABRUPTLY STOP. BRYAN (CONT’D) Troy? There is no sound. Then, a faint childish laugh. BRYAN (CONT’D) (freaked) Who’s down here! Silence. He moves down the creaking steps. Until his flashlight beam finds... Troy...eyes wide with fear...his throat ripped out. Terrified, Bryan feels something behind him. He hears a noise: breathing. He slowly turns, his beam ILLUMINATES: A blonde two year old BOY, wearing a Lindberg-era white christening gown with seed pearls long yellowed. His mout and face is smeared with blood, his skin is wrinkled like ancient man. The INFANTATA smiles, gurgles... Then ATTACKS. The lightlight falls to the ground. FADE TO BLACK.

INT. DOCTOR’S OFFICE -- DAY THE SOUND OF RUNNING WATER. Come up on a TRAY of INSTRUMENTS.  A stainless steel SPECULUM, a large SYRINGE with NEEDLE, COTTON SWABS, COTTON BALLS, RUBBER GLOVES. The water stop and the hands of DR. DAY come into view. He towels them o pulls on the gloves.
Are your periods regular again? He messes with the instruments as a WOMAN speaks. It’s VI HARMON.
Pretty much. Every other month. Dr. Day turns. REVEAL Vivien, gowned, on her back, her le in STIRRUPS. She’s pretty, forty, but she looks thirty fi
I’m not complaining. After all of that blood. Day inserts his gloved fingers into Vivien, beginning his exam. She takes in a sharp breath.
Ben hates blood.
How are you two doing? Sexual relations? Day is clinical. He’s not looking to get off here.
Sometimes. He inserts the speculum. She exhales. It hurts a little.
You having trouble with arousal?
A little. Thought maybe it was pre- menopause. He pulls out the speculum, takes off his gloves.
Could be. Any issues achieving climax?
I don’t know, it depends. When I’m alone it’s fine.  He nods.
Well, things look great from a physical standpoint. Are you anxious about having sex? About something happening?
You mean like getting pregnant?
It would be a normal response.
Well, I would like to go back on my birth control pills. He takes out her FILE. Writes --
I want to wait a beat on those. They can cause irregularities in your hormone levels and I think you're already having some issues in that department. Your cycle, the sexual issues.
I don’t have sexual issues. (then) Maybe I’m just depressed. Day takes a beat, then keeps writing -- that’s not his fi of expertise.
I’ve recently had some success with women your age using bioidentical hormone treatments. Estrogen, progestin.
Wait, so I am going through menopause?
I don’t think so. This is more of a pre-emptive strike. Your body is like a house, you can fix the tiles in the bathroom and the kitchen but if the foundation is decaying, you're wasting your time.
Are there any side effects?
The bHRT’s are great for your skin, your organs. Most of the women I give these to tell me they make them feel ten years younger.

I don’t let my family use plastic bottles or hold their cell phones to their ears, now you want me to put something in my body and not tell me side effects? Don’t they make those things with horse pee?
Feel and look ten years younger.
The arousal issue is mine, not Ben’s. I’m just reconnecting with my body after what happened, I don’t want to give it away again.
You’re worried about losing control, I’m offering you something to help you get it back.
I’m not a house.
Vivien, what are you so afraid of? Off Vivien, unsure of the answer --

Vivien comes home with GROCERIES. Goes into the KITCHEN. Starts unloading. Along with the food is a LITTLE PHARMAC bag. She pulls out the hormone pills and creams, looks at them, thinks, then HEARS A NOISE from upstairs. A piece o furniture being moved? Her eyes go wide. Then, the sound again, longer, louder. She’s TERRIFIED, dials the phone.
911 operator, what is your emergency?
(whispering) There’s someone in my house.
Are you sure it’s not a member of your family?
No. My daughter is at school and my husband is at work. I think someone is robbing us. Someone robbed the brownstone next door two weeks ago. What do I do?
We're sending a patrol car. She hears a THUNK -- like a body hitting the floor. She hangs up. Thinks. Grabs a KNIFE and starts upstairs.

ANGLE: on the gleaming knife at her side. More sounds. Vi slowly makes her way to the door, takes a deep breath and CREAKS it open. On her face, the blood rushing out of it. GIRL’S VOICE (0.S.) Oh shit. Vivien backs out into the hallway, almost goes over the railing. She’s going to throw up. Before she can, her husband, BEN comes out, naked. He’s 42, fit, handsome as is pretty.

Vivien.... He goes to hug her. She instinctively SLASHES at him with knife. It SCRAPES his arm. Both of them look at the small yet real wound, shocked. She drops the knife. He takes he in his arms and keeps repeating with hysteria...
I’m sorry I’m sorry I’m sorry... She lets him hold her for a beat, then breaks away in tea and runs down the stairs. Off a naked, bleeding Ben we SM TO BLACK.

DRIVING OVER THE GOLDEN GATE BRIDGE, SIX MONTHS LATER. Ha SUNLIGHT through the windows. Ben’s driving. Vivien in the passenger seat, staring out the window. Th fifteen year old GOTH daughter VIOLET in the back with si month old DOG, HALLIE.
Isn’t it beautiful?
The light is different from Boston. Feels like I can see more. I thought it was supposed to be all foggy.
I need to go to the bathroom.
It’s just a little while longer.
I need to go.
Where would you like me to pull over, sweetie -- the Bay or the Pacific?
(re: the dog) Bet if baby substitute had to shit you'd find somewhere.
I don’t like that word, Violet. A beat, then Violet looks out the window. Thoughtfully --

Thirteen hundred people have jumped off of this thing -- at least that’s what they think. They don’t see them all and they stopped counting right before a thousand. I looked it up. Twenty six of them survived. You know what all of them said was their first thought after they stepped off? (then, mischievous) Oh shit. Her mother’s discomfort makes Violet grin.
Kind of how I feel about this move. (then) I’m not going to like the school. San Francisco is filled with hippies and freaks and drug addicts.
I’m glad we named you Violet instead of our second choice.
Which was?
Sunshine. They all kind of crack up. A fleeting moment of family togetherness. Ben shares a smile with his wife, then reac out his hand to hold hers, but she PULLS it AWAY.

They pull into the driveway. Everyone takes a good look - it’s looking better than it did the last time we saw it. paint, shutters, gutters. There’s a FOR SALE sign on the lawn. All three of them take it in as they come to a stop
This is it. Vivien is unsure. Violet is intrigued. MARCY, the RELATOR greets them from the front porch with a WAVE.
Marcy shows them around. The FOYER is epic, beautiful, soaring ceilings and a grand STAIRCASE. House porn.

It’s the finest Queen Anne on the market. Venetian chandeliers, original moldings. The stained glass is some of the only of it’s kind that survived the great quake. As you can see the previous owners really loved the place like a child. They restored everything.
Gay?  10.
Sweetheart, it’s San Francisco, they’re all gay. Light laughter. Except from Violet, who rolls her eyes. B sees this and fights a laugh. They head into the KITCHEN.
It’s beautiful. Looks original except with all of the mod bells and whistles.
Do you cook?
Viv is a great cook. I got her cooking lessons a few years ago for her birthday and she ended up teaching the teacher a few things.
Cooking lessons. Romantic. You're a psychiatrist?
Psychologist. You said something on the phone about there being a study upstairs that I could use as a home office? I’m planning on seeing patients here so I can spend more time with the family.
How refreshing. Vivien shakes her head.
Hallie sniffs around, PEES in a corner, then SENSES SOMETHING. Explores, then -- STARTS BARKING LIKE CRAZY.
Violet is staring out the window at the BACKYARD.
Violet, will you go see what’s going on with Hallie? Violet storms out. Teenager.  11.
Violet finds Hallie, barking madly at the BASEMENT DOOR.

Shut up! She won’t. Violet looks at the door. It’s BOLTED SHUT. Ol school bolted. Two heavy bolts and two HUGE PADLOCKS. Someone doesn’t want to let anyone in -- or maybe out. Violet wiggles the doorknob, trying to pry it open.
From the BOTTOM of the steps. POV of something watching t door move, the knob jiggle. We hear it’s raspy breathing.
Violet tries the door a few more times, then yanks on the locks. No luck. She stares at the door, oddly drawn to it
Marcy shows Vivien and Ben the BEAUTIFUL GOTHIC LIBRARY.
This is my favorite room in the house.
(to Vivien, trying) When I saw the pictures of this room online I thought maybe you could use it as your music room.
You’re a musician?
I was.
She’s a cellist. She played in the Boston philharmonic. She heads over to the WALL. Something isn’t right.
Why did you quit? There’s an answer, but we’re not going to get it.  12.

This wallpaper is coming off. She goes to the wall, grabs a tiny PEELING PIECE of seagr wallpaper and gently pulls it off. It opens a small windo the ORIGINAL WALL, no bigger than a couple of postage sta
I think there’s a mural under here.
The last owners must have covered it up. They were modernists. (then, with difficulty) Speaking of the last owners, full disclosure requires me to tell you about what happened to them.
Oh God, one of them didn’t die in here, did they?
Yes, actually. Both of them. (off their shock) Murder suicide. I sold them the house, too. Just the sweetest couple. You never know I guess.
So that’s why it’s half the price of every other house in the neighborhood.
I have a very nice painted lady not too far from here but you’re going to get a third of the house for twice the price if you go that way. Vivien and Ben aren’t sure. Violet comes in carrying Hall
Where did it happen?
The basement. Another beat. Violet grins.
We'll take it. Off Ben and Vivien --  13.
As MOVERS finish bringing the last boxes in, Marcy pulls IN ESCROW sign off of the FOR SALE sign and replaces it w one that says SOLD.
Ben comes out the bathroom in his pajamas, happy. Vivien still unpacking, there are boxes everywhere. He comes in behind her, kisses her, she gently moves away.
Come to bed, we'll finish this in the morning.
I’m worried about Violet. She’s right about kids being different out here. She can’t handle another year of not fitting in.

You mean you can’t. (then) I treat kids like Violet every day. In three months she'll have lost all of the dark eye make up and combat boots and be walking around in Birkenstocks with unshaven pits smelling like patchouli. She laughs. He takes her in his arms.
It doesn’t freak you out at all? What happened here?
My repulsion is tempered by the fact that this house is worth four times what we paid for it.
But it’s not like some old lady died in here. A murder-suicide. Gives me the creeps just thinking about it.
So don’t think about it.  14.
That’s your professional advice, doctor?

No place is perfect. No place and no person. (then) All I know is that for the first time in months I feel at home somewhere. Moving here, buying this house was the right thing to do for our family. It’s a good thing and frankly, we deserve some good after all the shit we’ve been through. (then, realizing) Sorry. She nods, not sure, but desperate to trust him. He kisses her. Another fleeting moment, this one of marital bliss, she can’t sustain it. She pulls away, leaves him to go do more unpacking.

Violet walks through the commons, SMOKING. She surveys th scene -- a few kids reliving their grandparents’ Haight Ashbury fashion mistakes but most are unmemorable. Upper middle class high school in an upscale urban neighborhood She passes THREE pretty girls -- seniors dressed like the twenty-five -- talking up some boys -- LEAH, BECCA and AB Overhears their conversation --
So I let him.
Do coke off of your nipples?
They were numb for like two days. They all crack up. Violet tries to disappear into her swe as she passes, but --
Hey! Student council passed a rule against smoking in public spaces. The girls step in front of her.
Second hand smoke kills.  15. Violet puts the cigarette out.
I didn’t know. I’m new. Violet nervously flicks her butt into a planter. Leah fli
What the hell is the matter with you? People sit here. They eat here.
You don’t know me. Why are you doing this?
Leah’s grandma died of lung cancer. She takes this stuff pretty seriously. Leah holds the butt out to Violet.
Eat it. (off Violet’s shock) Eat it. Or I’m going to kick the shit out of you.
Come on, Leah, it’s enough.
No, I want to see her eat it. She grabs Violet’s face.

Seriously, Leah, she’s like twelve. Leah starts trying to shove the cigarette into Violet’s mouth, but Violet resists, then instinctively SPITS in Le face. That stuns everyone. Abby and Becca can’t help but laugh. A beat, then Violet takes off running.
(calling after her) You're dead! DEAD!  16.

Vivien drops the NEEDLE on an old record player. Classica cello plays as she sets out her INSTRUMENTS -- a large bo of water, scraping tool, small knife. Slowly and carefull she starts removing the old wallpaper. As she does, the GOYA-ESQUE MURAL begins to reveal itself She can’t quite make out the first image -- until she pul off one more sliver or paper to see -- A WOMAN, her face in pain, her body twisted and tortured. Vivien stares at the image, transfixed and disturbed when suddenly a HAND touches her shoulder. She jumps out of he skin, turns, sees ADELAIDE, the child with Down Syndrome saw earlier, now a woman in her forties.
You’re going to die in here.

Adelaide! Constance, Adelaide’s mother enters from the kitchen carr a BOX. Constance is a chain smoker, and she sounds like i CONSTANCE (CONT’D) Adelaide. I put that “Dora the Explorer” on for you so you would sit and watch it.
It was “Go Diego Go.” I don’t like it.

Brown cartoon characters -- you can’t tell the difference. Vivien doesn’t know what to make of this. Finally -- CONSTANCE (CONT’D) Hi. Hi. I’m Constance your neighbor -- the tear down next door. This is my girl Adelaide. Go home Addy. Now! Adelaide storms out. CONSTANCE (CONT’D) That girl is a monster. I love her and I’m a good Christian but Jesus A. (MORE )
CONSTANCE (CONT’D) Christ, if they’d invented some of those tests a few years earlier...
How did you get in my house?
You left your back door open, though I have to warn you Addy seems to always find a way in. She’s got a bug up her ass for this place, always has. You got a dog?
Yes. Is that a problem?
Better for me. I run a little kennel out of my house. Doggy day care kind of thing. Don’t bother calling the cops on me -- I’m in with one of the city managers and he always looks the other way.
Look, it’s very nice to meet you but I wasn’t really prepared for company.

I’m gone. Brought this for you, housewarming. Addy wanted to cook you a pie but she tends to spit in the cooking so I figured this was better -- should help you get rid of some of the bad ju-ju. She hands Vivien the box. CONSTANCE (CONT’D) Those homosexual boys were nice enough and I say live and let live, but I can’t help but think that that lifestyle drove them to do what they did. (then) I can’t remember your name.
I didn’t tell you. I’m Vivien Harmon.  18.

Anyway, enjoy, relax, let me know if you need help with your pup. Glad you’re getting rid of that wallpaper. Thought those people were supposed to be stylish. She exits. Vivien can’t help but laugh a little at their oddity. She shakes her head, opens the box to see a TIGHT WOUND BUNCH OF SAGE. A beat, then -- through the window s sees Constance walking back to her house. CONSTANCE (CONT’D) (calling back) It’s Sage. For cleansing the spirits in the house. Too many bad memories in there.
Vivien moves through the house, the burning sage bundle i her hand. She’s not sure if she buys this whole cleansing spirits thing, but she’s committing. She moves into an

She hasn't spent much time in this part of the house yet. It’s barely decorated and there are even a few EMPTY BOXE stacked at the dead end. Suddenly, the flame in the sage bundle is BLOWN OUT. Odd. She looks UP for the source and discovers a DRAFT coming from a TRAP DOOR IN THE CEILING. The attic. She puts down the sage, pulls over a chair. Standing on i she pulls the DRAWSTRING.

The DOOR opens and STAIRS extend into the hallway. Common these old houses. She climbs in. DARKNESS, SILENCE. Her e adjust. Miraculously, she finds a LIGHT CORD, pulls it. The single bulb turns on and she’s standing face to face a BLACK RUBBER MAN.
Ben is on the bed, reading when he hears his wife SCREAM.
Ben rushes up the stairs, finds Vivien sitting on some ST of old newspapers.  19.

What happened? Are you okay? She points to the rubber man -- he’s actually just a larg rubber suit -- known as a RUBBER ASPHYXIATION SUIT hangin from a hook. The suit is black, covers the entire body an has a mask with two small eye holes and two tiny breathin straws that can be pinched to temporarily suffocate the wearer.
Guess those guys were into the kinky stuff. (then) Should I try it on?
Stop it. It’s not funny. But they laugh. A beat, then Violet peeks her head in.
What happened? (seeing the suit) Holy shit.
Get it out of here.

Ben tosses the suit in the GARBAGE. INT. BEN’S HOME OFFICE -- DAY TIGHT on various items as we hear a therapy session. Ben’ diploma from Yale; psychiatric books he has written. BEN’S VOICE These fantasies started, two years ago, three years ago...?
Two years. We see Ben, very calm and professional in his shrink chai
Is there a structure to the thoughts...a pattern...
It’s always the same, it starts the same way.  20.
How?
I prepare for the noble war. We REVEAL TATE LANGDON...17, handsome, charismatic as hell...he could be a cult leader or a movie star.
I get a taste for the bloodletting...and I pack up my weapons of mass destruction.
INT. VIOLET’S BEDROOM -- SIMULTANEOUS Violet neatly unpacks razor blades, raises one, examines
Guns?
Obviously.
And then?

Tate walks through a crowded hallway, smiling sweetly, wearing a trenchcoat and holding a duffel bag. TATE’S VOICE I’m walking through the halls, I’m calm, I have the secret, I know what’s coming and I know no one can stop me, including myself. BEN’S VOICE Do you target people who have been mean to you? Unkind? TATE’S VOICE No. I kill people I like. In the hall, a SWEET INNOCENT 16-YEAR-OLD GIRL smiles at He smiles back. BEN’S VOICE Do you feel sympathy?  21. TATE’S VOICE No. I’m helping them.
Typical algebra tedium. Until Tate enters.
Can I help you?
No. He RAISES HIS GUN, shoots the teacher. She instantly goes down. Tate looks at the shocked students, who are paralyz He starts roaming the aisles and just shooting.

Some of them beg for their life, but I don’t feel sad, I don’t feel anything. Its a filthy world we live in, a filthy goddamned helpless world, and honestly? I feel I’m taking them away from all the shit and piss and vomit that runs in the streets, you know? I’m helping to take them somewhere clean and silent and kind.

The entire classroom has been massacred, the walls are bl smeared. The sweet girl from the hallway has been badly wounded, but she’s not dead. He stops in front of her, ai the gun. She raises her shaking hand, we SEE him through gaping bullet hole.
Please... He shoots her dead.
There’s something about the blood, man. All that blood. I drown in it.

Tate is bounding down the stairwell, to escape. He hears something, stops turns.  22. A TORRENT OF BLOOD, A WALL OF IT, races down the stairwel him. He spreads his arms, to welcome it. It envelopes him is obliterated.
Ben shows no emotion, writes SOCIOPATH on his tablet.

The Indians believed that blood holds all the bad spirits, they would cut themselves once a month in ceremonies, let the spirits go free. There’s something smart about that. Very smart. I like that. INT. VIOLET’S BEDROOM -- SIMULTANEOUS Violet cuts herself with the razor blade. She stares at t crimson gash on her arm with no emotion.
You think I’m crazy?
No. I think you’re creative, and I think you have a lot of pain you're not dealing with.
My mother’s worried about me.
Yes.

She’s a cocksucker. I mean, literally, she’s a cocksucker. She sucked the guy off next door all the time, my dad found out, he left. He left me alone with a cocksucker, can you imagine? How sick is that? Tate for the first time shows vulnerability.

I’m not crazy, dude. Don’t you think it’s interesting? The idea of letting the bad blood out? The worlds a filthy place. A goddamned horror show. So much pain. So much.  23. INT. VIOLET’S ROOM -- DAY Violet makes another cut.
You’re doing it wrong. She whirls around, revealing --
If you’re trying to kill yourself, cut vertically. They can’t stitch that up.
(freaked) How’d you get in here?
If you’re trying to kill yourself you might also try locking the door. He leaves. She stares.

Middle of the night. So quiet you can hear the buzz of th DIGITAL CLOCK. Ben and Vivien in bed. Suddenly, from abov we see BEN’S EYES SPRING OPEN. There’s no life behind the though. He gets up, SLEEPWALKING.
Ben, NAKED, walks down the stairs. The house CREAKS, GROA

IN THE SHADOWS we can make out some more of the mural. It a HELLSCAPE. QUICK CUTS as Ben KNEELS down, turns on the in the fireplace, LIGHTS a ROLL OF NEWSPAPER, tosses it o the logs, IGNITING A HUGE FIRE. He stands, watches the fire. The room and his naked form GLOWS. As if he was reaching for a long lost love he reac out to the fire, closer. Then --
Ben! Ben pulls his hand back, turns to see his wife. He’s stil not with it.  24.
What are you doing? You’re naked. Come back to bed.
Am I in a dream? Vivien softens, goes to him, starts leading him back.
No, you're sleepwalking. She leads him out, turns to look at the fire as she does catches a glimpse of the MURAL as we...
Vivien hangs BEDSHEETS up on clothes lines, drying them. It’s peaceful, golden light, an easy breeze. A TALL WOMAN her sixties comes around into the backyard.
Can I help you?
I’m Moira O'Hara, I’m the housekeeper.
I didn’t know the place came with one.
Why are you hanging your sheets? Perfectly good electric dryer inside.
I don’t like the chemicals in fabric softener and the organic ones don’t work. This is the only way to dry them without static cling. Moira’s impressed.

I work Monday through Thursday. Four hundred a week. If you have a dinner party and you want me to serve or straighten up, it’s extra. Thanksgiving on, Christmas off. That was the deal with the last fellows.
I’m sorry, I’m just not sure if we need a maid.
What have you been using to clean the floorboards?
Murphy’s oil soap.  26.
No. White Vinegar. Oil soap kills the wood. Have you ever owned a house this old?
No.
It has a personality, feelings. Mistreat it and you will regret it. Trust me, madam, you need me. (then) May I come in? My cab’s left and I’d like to call another. Off Vivien --
Vivien brings Moira some TEA.
You worked for the previous owners?

And the ones before that. I’ve been the housekeeper here for years. They come, they go, I stay. My husband has been ill for some time so I’m the breadwinner. (then) They were both nice boys, the ones before you. I found the bodies.
What happened? I mean, I hate to gossip.
I don’t know. They fought a lot. Money I think. Who can know when something so horrible happens? Sometimes people just go mad. (then, hushed) I cleaned the mess. You’d never know. Ben enters.
Ben, this is Moira O’Hara, she’s the last owner’s housekeeper. (MORE )
Well, actually she’s been working here for years. Moira turns to greet Ben. Ben’s POV -- she’s a STUNNING TWENTY-FIVE-YEAR OLD. Tiny waist, succulent breasts.
Nice to meet you, Moira. They shake. Moira smiles, so hot. Her eyes cry sex. There the sound She exits. of a CAR HORN.
That’s my cab. I'’11 use the lavatory first if you don’t mind.
What do you think?
Wait, you want to hire her?
She’s a bit of character but she’s also the first person I’ve met since we moved here that I actually like.
(a beat, confused) How long has she been working here?
I don’t know exactly. The point is that she knows the house, she seems honest and I could use the help. Ben is baffled. She smiles as Moira comes back in. Vivien talks to her so Moira is old again.
Can you start tomorrow?
Thursday’s better but I’1l1 make it work. She nods to both of them -- they both see different Moira and leaves.  28.
(noticing something) What? Ben takes her in his arms.
Nothing. You just always surprise me. She likes that. He kisses her. Things get passionate. She wants to give in, but can’t. She pulls away.
You know, you’re going to have to forgive me one day. He’s hurt, exits. She shakes her head, disappointed in herself. How long does she have to hold on to this?
Vivien digs through the VANITY, finds the old PRESCRIPTIO BAG. Tears it open, removes the HORMONE REPLACEMENT MEDS Day gave her. She fills a cup with water, SWALLOWS A PILL
TIGHT on bolt-cutters slicing through the locks.
Ben and Violet enters to investigate. There’s really noth here now but dust and an odd piece of unloved furniture.
Crap.
What?
This is where those dudes killed themselves, right? I thought maybe we'd find a body or something. Ben looks at her, laughs. So does she. A beat, he puts hi arms around her shoulders. Brightly --
Okay! I’ve really enjoyed this father daughter bonding time. He leaves. Violet takes a beat, then follows.  29.
